review.title: Inferring Narrative Causality between Event Pairs in Films
review.abstract: To understand narrative, humans draw inferences about the underlying relations between narrative events. Cognitive theories of narrative understanding define these inferences as four different types of causality, that include pairs of events A, B where A physically causes B (X drop, X break), to pairs of events where A causes emotional state B (Y saw X, Y felt fear). Previous work on learning narrative relations from text has either focused on "strict" physical causality, or has been vague about what relation is being learned. This paper learns pairs of causal events from a corpus of film scene descriptions which are action rich and tend to be told in chronological order. We show that event pairs induced using our methods are of high quality and are judged to have a stronger causal relation than event pairs from Rel-grams.

sections.heading: 3.3 Narrative Causality Types
sections.text: Although narrative causality theories postulate four different types of narrative causality, previous work has not conducted reliability studies with non-experts such as Turks. Here, we investigate whether people can distinguish narrative causality types by asking Turks to decide what relationship exists between a pair of events, and the instructions contain descriptions of narrative causality types and the strength of these relationships (from strong to weak: PHYSICAL, MOTIVATIONAL, PSYCHOLOGICAL, and ENABLUNG (Trabasso et al., 1989)). As the stronger types of narrative causality can also be considered as ENABLUNG, Turks are instructed to choose the strongest narrative causality that can be applied to the event pairs. We randomly select 100 pairs from the high CPC pairs of the 479 questions that had the highest agreement among Turks. sections.heading: 4 Related Work
sections.text: Hu et al. (2013) tested four methods to induce pairs of adjacent events with contingency / causality relationships from film scenes, including causal potential, pointwise mutual information, bigram model, and protagonist-based model. Rahimtoroghi et al. (2016) also used a modified version of the CP metric, adapted to the discourse structure of personal narratives in blogs. Here, we use a much larger set of films and apply different techniques and detailed evaluation. Our learned causal pairs and supporting film data are available for download 6.Do et al. (2011) used a minimally revised approach based on focused distribution methods and discourse connections to identify fy6https: / / nlds.soe.ucsc.edu / narrativecausalitycausalitycausalitycausalitycausality relations between events in PDTB context (both verbal and noun).

sections.heading: 5 Discussion and Future Work
sections.text: We present an unsupervised model based on the causal potential (Beamer and Girju, 2009) to induce event pairs with narrative causal relationships from film scenes in 11 genres. Results from four human evaluations show that narrative causal pairs generated with our method are of high quality and perceived as causally related as corresponding descriptions. We show that people can identify different types of narrative causal relationships, but we leave the automatic identification to this future work. We also show that the induction of narrative causal relationships using both whole corpus and genre-specific methods yields similar results in terms of quality, despite the smaller size of the genre-specific subcorpus. Furthermore, the genre-specific method learns high-quality event pairs that differ from event pairs throughout the corpus. We investigate the application and evaluation of our CPC method to other genre-specific subcorpus narratives, and we may wish to contribute to the understanding of potential event pairings as well as our personal data sets and specific blog posts.
